summary: This is an internal FBI email chain from June 2019 discussing the logistical and legal hurdles of transferring investigative documents related to Jeffrey Epstein from the FBI's Miami Field Office (MM) to the Southern District of New York (SDNY) in preparation for Epstein's imminent indictment. The emails reveal coordination issues and a tight timeline ahead of the planned arrest.

persons.name: SSA FBI New York
persons.context: Appears as the sender/recipient in the email chain, coordinating the document transfer process between FBI offices and SDNY.

events.title: Planned Indictment of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: The FBI New York office states they plan to indict Jeffrey Epstein on the Tuesday following the email (June 26, 2019), which would be July 2, 2019. The arrest timing is contingent on his travel back to the US.

events.title: Meeting with SDNY Chief of Criminal
events.description: An FBI representative met with the SDNY Chief of Criminal the prior Thursday (June 20, 2019) to discuss concerns over document transfer delays.

keyFacts: The FBI was actively planning to indict Jeffrey Epstein in late June/early July 2019, with a target date of Tuesday, July 2, 2019.
At the time of the emails, Jeffrey Epstein was outside the continental United States (OCONUS), and his arrest was planned for when he returned to the US.

There was significant inter-agency coordination and pressure to transfer documents from the FBI's Miami Field Office (MM/WPBRA investigation) to the Southern District of New York (SDNY) to support the indictment and potential expedited trial.
The FBI's Office of General Counsel (OGC) initially would not authorize the release of the original files, leading to a pursuit of a 'doclab' digitization option as an alternative.
The email chain highlights internal FBI efforts to avoid an 'escalation' from the SDNY regarding the document transfer delays.
